title: US appeals court rules against broad enforcement of travel ban
text:
A US appeals court Thursday ruled against President Donald Trump’s effort to broadly enforce a temporary travel and refugee ban on people from certain Muslim-majority countries that the Republican president said was necessary for national security.

A three-judge 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals panel said the government did not persuasively explain why the travel ban should be enforced against grandparents, grandchildren, aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews and cousins from the six countries.

In the latest legal back-and-forth over the president’s controversial executive order, the court also said refugee resettlement agencies have a “bona fide” relationship with refugees, which under a standard set by the US Supreme Court should allow them into the United States.
summary:
A US appeals court Thursday ruled against President Donald Trump’s effort to broadly enforce a temporary travel and refugee ban on people from certain Muslim-majority countries that the Republican president said was necessary for national security.
A three-judge 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals panel said the government did not persuasively explain why the travel ban should be enforced against grandparents, grandchildren, aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews and cousins from the six countries.
In the latest legal back-and-forth over the president’s controversial executive order, the court also said refugee resettlement agencies have a “bona fide” relationship with refugees, which under a standard set by the US Supreme Court should allow them into the United States.
